page.title: 12Industry - Brickworks
page.content: In 1937 Commander Viner, who lived at Fountains Abbey set up businesses in Northumberland for the Jarrow unemployed and built the village of Swarland, also a Tweed mill and a Saw mill at Amble. He also built a Brick works on the site of an old Tilery at Thrunton. There were 35 employees and operations were labour intensive. When the 1939-45 war broke out, workers from Jarrow returned to the shipyards. Early in the war, bricks were made for military projects, but the works had to close down and became a Ministry of Food Depot. The Blythes bought the brickworks in 1942. The works reopened after the war and nowadays are well mechanised, employ 28 men and produce common bricks and 9 varieties of facing bricks.
